1118641527016783872.text: 8) I think there is currently more downside to being a crypto investor than an entrepreneur, because investing in crypto tokens challenges traditional western investing practices, as we are and will be in a retail-dominated market for the foreseeable future

1118641525569855488.text: 7) low down side risk - it has to mean something when @jpmorgan , China’s central government, @facebook and @Samsung are all somehow talking about the same technology, right?

1118641524454166529.text:
6) 

On the funding ’s side, there are so much capital and resources at the entrepreneurs' disposal 

Everyone is desperate for you to build on their platforms- you have capital from foundations, accelerators, protocol hackathons and funds. Even international funds

1118641523409731584.text:
5) 

identifying the “right market timing” no longer holds the same importance 

In crypto, there can be multiple “right timing” situations, depending on location and jurisdiction. If you can’t find market adoption in one place, you may well likely find it in another

1118641522440904705.text:
4) 

Given the interdisciplinary nature of this space, crypto has opened up new opportunities for entrepreneurs who can connect the dots cross-industries and cross-borders

1118641521077649408.text:
3) 

Identifying one’s business niche is magnitudes easier in crypto

1118641519836188672.text:
2) 

Entrepreneurs don’t need a track record to validate themselves or to build a business in the crypto space

And any of their former damaged reputation/lackluster professional experiences will barely affect them, as long as they can add impactful value and attract talent

1118641517651009536.text:
1) 

Given the digital/distributed nature of crypto, entrepreneurs get low cost/ free access to a diverse community to test their hypothesis or minimal viable product that no traditional tech entrepreneurs had the luxury of accessing

1100805159200919557.text: Thoughts? Questions? Anything else you guys are seeing can help with startup companies in crypto?

1100805158093639681.text: Another tip early on is to have a combined group of traditional b2b veterans (senior folks in Corp dev, sales) and crypto native individuals to be your sounding board and industry consultant

1100805156810170368.text: For example if you look at our mentorship program at @BlockchainsFor Schools, we have folks like cofounder of Livepeer and members from the ethereum foundation who are committed to the space and actually wants to give back to the community

1100805155698733056.text:
I do recognize that this filtering process is one of thehardest things to identify

So how should one do it? 

I think in the crypto community- it’s about identifying the smartest people you know and finding those who are committed to the industry for the long haul

1100805154641715200.text: For b2b founders, u should be super picky and disciplined about what type of projects you work with bc you don’t want to get bogged down with a customer who ask the most ridiculous tool to be built that won’t be used by anyone else, unless it’s like big guys like Facebook or

1100805153660329984.text: What I hate to see is teams spending their effort building a whole suite of solution for one customer because of their specific needs, and then the customer decides to shut down

1100805152381026305.text: For crypto b2b businesses I think it’s focusing on the identifying the best type of customers for you and constantly revisit that thesis (bc crypto is changing too quickly), focus on coming up with backup plans and alternative customer base should the original not work

1100805151407906818.text: This is why FOCUS is the single most important priority for a founder. And that means many things and differnt for differnt businesses ie

1100805150015401985.text: What’s also distracting is that many crypto projects running on remaining ICO $ are unintentionally misleading these founders into working on products that won’t be sustainable bc these projects won’t be able raise a series A post ico - I’m guessin that’s like 90% of ICO projects

1100805149075931137.text: For a b2b startup that’s trying to find product market fit in the crypto space, there are so many different and diverse needs at the moment: analytics, developer tools, distributed task management, reporting, and basic infrastructure setup

1100805147968659456.text: Nevertheless, partially as a result of such mindset, identifying product market fit becomes even harder for these founders

1096435502142681089.text: Many readers may not know that Tezos is structured as a group of legally and managerially independent organizations. Out of the 5 legally setup foundations around the world, 4 of them are in Asia- @Tezos_Korea , @AsiaTezos @TezosJapan @TezosHK China

1096435498250317825.text: I went to a @Tezos_Korea conference  a few weeks ago and saw how interest for blockchain technology is still alive and well among many students, executives and developers. I documented my experience there and shared it in my discussion with @laurashinhttps://globalcoinresearch.com/2019/02/10/tezos-korea-plans-to-rejuvenate-koreas-blockchain-communities/ …

1096435496807555072.text: As it is still early in the blockchain space, the first organizations that can tap into this growing developer pool could potentially capture a large mind share. We are seeing that with Ethereum and Tezos.

1096435495612096513.text: There are talented tech developers and teams all over the world. However, It’s important to recognize that while many blockchain projects can be easily copied and forked, creating a great developer community is much harder.

1096435494068596737.text: Now that we are in a bear market, with the local Korean exchanges either under scrutiny or downsizing, I think the next ( or resurfacing) opportunity in Korea is to focus on the developer and student community.
